text: I can answer regarding the royalty feature on

On Ethereum, royalties are platform dependent. That means that when you set royalties on rarible, but gets sold on Opensea, you don't get royalties. On NEAR, we developed the NFT standard with NEAR that means that royalties are forever engraved in the token and not platform dependent. You can share royalties with up to 20 people

text:
I don't think there should be any restrictions on what guild members want to do, or the tools that we use, across the entire ecosystem. But it's important to note that NxM stands for NEARxMusic, and that support for the activities the guild embarks on should add to the growth of NEAR in one form or another.

Bounties will be paid in NEAR, the current DAO for the guild is using Sputnik, which is part of the NEAR ecosystem. No one here needs to be exclusively tied to NEAR and of course, as the entire ecosystem grows, we are going to see more seamless interoperability, allowing us to do a whole lot more. So finding ways to integrate the tools we need as musicians are important. Like how we use Cryptovoxels for example.

That said, if a guild member was to request funding that doesn't benefit the guild (NEAR) it would be hard to justify awarding the funds. Hope that helps explain things a bit better.

messages.text: What I need to talk about with you Vandal is that my new podcast is having guest musicians doing the intro and outro and I wanted to organise a system to royalty share from the podcast with nfts in mintbase and have some funding there to help onboard those musicians with near wallets and into this guild ^^
We have a lot of producers in here. Maybe you can get some of their beats for the podcast and include their near name in the royalty split!
So the way that it works is that we've got some lyrics via the lovely robotic Poetic Artificial Intelligence that musicians are encouraged to use how they like (and widely)
And the way I was thinking that royalty was best shared was in a mutual fund, where after you do the podcast you're entitled to one share of generated income

And it's designed to be a zero-qualifier open call. The only limit is that the intro and outro need to be shorter than the total podcast length of 30 minutes and you have to use the work by PAI *somehow*. I hope that a lot of musicians who wouldn't usually do stuff like this would get involved

messages.text:
Awesome! I wish I could do Thursday morning my week is slammed with festival planning and NFT launches but I‚Äôm Amber. I run nashville unsigned - digital magazine , label services , live events and community for independent artists. 

We are currently working on the live event space through festivals  

We‚Äôve also started a minting and marketing company in the music space called Unsigned NFT. Focusing on independent artist NFT‚Äôs and a marketplace to find independent NFT‚Äôs. And a group on Facebook called NFT Music Community. Our vision is creating revenue streams that allow for these pro level indie artist to not only succeed but to flourish in their career and to also get educated and using crypto if they aren‚Äôt already. 


We are also working in the sync licensing space to hopefully run licensing through NFT‚Äôs and also a PRO for a niche genre. 

So a lot! Lol but our most exciting is the festival scene. We are doing musictree festival and the kickoff party for Bonnaroo this year as well. 

 we are just stoked to be in this community. Thanks for having us!
Hi guys sorry been a bit quiet. Good news is I‚Äôm back :) The hackathon looks like it‚Äôll be fun!

messages.text: Hi all...something I keep getting asked by non-crypto musicians that I'm trying to onboard is how minting an NFT affects copyright. I've obviously had a look around...and read lots of different opinions...but it would be really useful to have a definitive answer. Anyone want to point me to it pls?....
...might be something for an onboarding bounty if someone wants to write it out...?

I believe an NFT artist‚Äôs work has two lives. That is for a C visual artist. 

The life on blockchain (NFTs) and the physical life (CDs, Prints, etc.)

And the person with the NFT doesn‚Äôt have a full ownership of the rights to the piece. Just an NFT life of that piece of work - for bragging rights or to hold as a form of value. 

This works in the visual art space and I think can translate in the audio space with little or no adjustments
I would suggest if you don't own the rights to the content you probably shouldn't sell it without including the other IP rights holders
Of course, when you sell the NFT you can assign IP to the buyer, but that's also tricky (SEC regulation)
It‚Äôs always great for audio artists under record labels to verify with their labels about putting out NFTs.
I would imagine independent labels who have deals in place with their artists could set up their collection/store and work in the splits that way.
That‚Äôs the best way to look at it.
Since they‚Äôll be new in the space
Providing information, technical know-how, platform and PR
hey so if anyone wants to come in and ideate around the NxM Community Token come join us in the Airmeet
Very good talk, too bad I'm on a mobile... it cut when breakaway started.

hmm...i wonder about where a recording artist is using samples...or in the case I'm interested in atm...doing a cover version. Appreciate that the smart contract can separate royalites perfectly to multiple users...but.....
That's my understanding...but there is some variation in opinion out there...
Can you share the other variant opinions on here?

I get it. Yeah I think that's something that traditionally people haven't worried too much about unless you're making enough money from it to not be under the radar. So unless you 'clear' the samples you're not really allowed to release and monetize the content, though people still do it. I think the same would apply for cover songs. You would probably need to negotiate all of that ahead of time.

Sorry for the stream of text, and I think  I might be preaching to the choir here, but I wrote this up, and I think it's important. Would love to hear everyone's thoughts. 

We‚Äôve been asked a thousand times at IMT why we‚Äôre doing our debut album launch primarily in the crypto and NFT space. The short answer is that it allows us to connect directly to our fans. The long answer is more complicated. 

Since the early 2000s, and the beginnings of the streaming revolution- the birth of Spotify and places like it- musicians latched onto the promise of delivering their music to listeners across the world. Unfortunately, that came with a cost- mainly that EP and Album sales, which were the primary source of revenue before that point, went into the toilet as a result. Streaming services know that you need them in the current industry.

In order to make $1000 USD, you‚Äôd have to have a song streamed 333,333 times on Spotify. That‚Äôs not enough to live on as a musician unless you‚Äôre a big name. The way artists made this up was through more touring and more live shows. With Covid-19 ravaging the world this past year, that other source of income was and is completely devastated. Thankfully, we‚Äôve been able to shift into the crypto and nft space with the help of Mango from Charged particles and other pioneers such as Dao Records and TokenSmart.

One event, one nft sale for us became the equivalent of millions of streams. It‚Äôs allowed us to continue being full-time NFT Musicians, and making music when most of the industry is shut down across the globe, when our friends and colleagues are struggling and out of work. This is only achievable by having fans invest in collectables directly from us while performing for an audience in the Metaverse. You don't need a middleman in the NFT Music space.

This is the future, and more musicians need to recognize it.

messages.text:
I'm in that predicament, I'm about to launch a media company and use it to launch my bands latest record but I now I can't launch it only on the NFT space because bookers, newsmedia, fans, etc... already expect us to have stuff in spotify and friends. 
The problem is to explore this new ways like NFTs of keeping in touch with the audience and making money while not abandoning the current model. 

Being said that, this technologies are a light at the end of the tunnel for independent artists :D
a boy band with a variety of genres :P
Sheesh I‚Äôm so behind here...vanish for 2 days and golly
Btw I just saw on Reddit that mintbase is looking for a brand & ui designer

No doubt! I've opted out of the current traditional model and am rarifying my older work. I'm a bit of a contrarian though, so I think if people appreciate the music and the artist they will go to where they are to listen. As much as we feel the need to be on major streaming services, aren't we just perpetuating their use and preventing those true fans from enjoying Audio NFTs and streaming via Audius or Emanate? My main problem with Spotify and the gang is that you have no direct relationship to the listener, you only know what country they're from and how many streams (which when audited by Beatdapp showed under-reporting of 15-30%) Just some things to think of...
yes! they've been looking for a while!
Welcome! I know a lot of musicians here are looking to collaborate with visual artists so feel free to drop an introduciton!
also the artist payout is so abysmal...it would be great to somehow shift the paradigm away altogether
Definitely one of the main reasons right here

I agree, in the end this "streaming" model is the same "record label" model presented in a different medium. The hard part about opting out is not access to the audience (you have to do your marketing anyway) it's the "validation" for bookers, promoters, media, etc... that are very important for live bands.
But I like to be positive and look for new business models and I think this is a very promisign one

I mean, we're also launching in trad media, but it wont be until a full month after the crytpo launch. I don't think it'd be smart to completely abandon the traditional model, but it *does* make sense for us to adapt to the advantages of this space.
that is also what I want to do

It's what works best for every artist, whether that's a combination of traditional and blockchain elements or just one. Audio NFTs should enable the artist (or Label) to be their own streaming platform. Once we figure out the audio NFT streaming side of things!
Yeah. I'd agree with vandal here. There's a few things still to be sorted, but it's something that's coming.
That's why we're here! To build out the components of a new Music Industry ecosystem üíØüî•

while I understand the importance of funding for the creation of music for projects or touring, I feel like it's a bit outside of the current scope of the guild and the objectives of the 'hackathon' for which the current round of funding is allocated for.

We don't yet have the means to fund artists' studio time or touring, but it is something that we would like to see in the future, as I see the value in both your ideas.

If you have thoughts around projects that focus on creating a DAO/Initiative that other community members can participate in, or that deals with the current needs of NxM (Onboarding, Social Media, Documentation, Educational Material, Events..) and that bring value to all members or the NEAR ecosystem, then those are the type of proposals that have the most potential to be funded. 

That said, you can still follow the "
" and still have the ability to earn up to 100 N without the need for your proposal to pass.

text.text: Important reminder for all NEAR wallet account holders!!

text: Once you create your account, under -

- I recommend that you secure your account (Security & Recovery) with both "Seed Phrase" and "Email".

The Seed Phrase generated when you do this IS DIFFERENT from the one you used when you created your account (I just noticed this and might be why a few of you weren't able to get back in with your seed phrase). Make sure to save the NEW seed phrase in your important files and/or in your password manager!

text: Beat Kitchen Challenge is a weekly beat making challenge, Production Studio and Live Streaming show that i host.  The show currently airs on Saturdays at 2pm Eastern Standard Time via my Twitch page and Instagram account.¬†¬†Each week (Saturday) i provides a new download link containing a folder of five songs or a folder of sounds that participants are then asked to create beats of any genre from.¬†¬†Participants are then given a week (from the Saturday the link is made available to following week‚Äôs Friday) to create their beats and then submit their beats to the Beat Kitchen email account by 12am Friday.¬†¬†Beat submissions are then showcased during the Live stream.¬†¬†The download link is made available via the Beat Kitchen Instagram page (link in page bio), or by becoming a member of the Beat Kitchen email mailing list. This challenge is open to everyone and anyone who is interested, no matter the level of production expertise.¬†¬†Past beat and video submissions are available on the Soundcloud and Instagram page.

0.19 thanks for the conversation as well. And no need to worry about offending ü•∞.

Audius is far from perfect üòÖ, but I definitely like that it's a platform that's trying to give some power back to the creators and their communities. A step in the right direction imo. üëåüèΩ

bring up good points. And Chloe really gets to the heart of my same sentiment in that it isn‚Äôt perfect, but it‚Äôs a step in the right direction. It‚Äôs definitely not a good look that Audius wins a lot of their own payouts, and that there are no direct payouts to artists beyond hitting Top 5 in streams or playlisting serves the platform more than the artist. But at no cost to upload, still a significant improvement on traditional major platforms. I‚Äôve heard really promising things about Beatify, but don‚Äôt personally have experience.

messages.text: But I also look at all blockchain projects as work in progress. And maybe give more leeway in certain regard due to that ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Seems like gating content is more the way to go, but still need to think through things. Just being able to purchase tunes that gives the owner the licensed ability to remix it for other bits is a win and low hanging fruit.

messages.text: Am I crazy to think we can do better than just an equivalent? How do artists monetize on the Audius platform? Don‚Äôt get me wrong ~ they have a great product. I‚Äôm just not sure if it solves the overarching problem...
only if you're in the top playlists you can get rewards
I'm sure we can create something better, more integrated and rewarding, with all the tools in the Near ecosystem, it should be super awesome!
what I miss from any streaming service is instant and direct rewards for playback (regardless if you're in the top playlists or not). should be possible to solve on NEAR.

The most challenging issue is IP and copyright. To prevent people who don't own the rights to upload and monetize any NFT or streaming.. I think Emanate has accomplished this. They might be the closest model to explore.
I've got stuff up with them
Yeah it‚Äôs a challenge to prevent technically. So easy to rip music from a stream.

Totally hear you. In my mind, it was more using an existing tool to highlight our community, and have that be an on-ramp for new musicians, since playlist placement is a significant draw for many. And less so about being on audius. Most ideally, we see the NEAR equivalent (and totally with Vandal and James in that we could do better) and would use that as the on-ramp. But I will be honest in that I didn‚Äôt know what platform audius was built on and hadn‚Äôt previously had that consideration, and was more looking at it as just access to the blockchain community of musicians, so definitely appreciate the different perspectives and considerations to look at and be aware of! Still learning!

messages.text: Heya, did any of you already sell an NFT that included a physical version of the album/ep or a download link for example?

text: There have been a number of sales, not specifically from Mintbase though, that have had physical items attached. I know myself and

, I am asking to understand what would be the best way to do so. Like including a link that redirects to a shopping basked where thy physica item is already inncluded for example, or a form where buyer leaves his/her address and the album would be sent manually

messages.text: a link to a google form, or an email for them to send their address. mostly it's been items we've created ourselves, so we ship them off
okay. We were thinking redirecting to another website that is related could also be nice. thank you!

text: sorry last question, for the physical items, you would have shipping costs already included in the price in N I assume? Considering that shipping would be possible worldwide

messages.text: On mintbase you can add a website for any mint you create. Imo one of the simplest ways could be to add a site to the mint and use that site to manage the actually physical part.

Purchase of the NFT can be completely on chain, while the physical transfer completely off chain. If a user wants to receive the physical good, they just need to click the website link, fill or the form you have there to get in touch with you, and you can handle that however works best. As volumes of sales increase, a tool could be created, like a simple redeamer app like Nate was talking about recently.

NFT can be traded in the open market, once someone wants to redeem, they go back to the merchant and transact to "burn" (or in some way modify the NFT to make it clear it has been used) and then receive the physical good. 

Simplest way to go about this part imo is to simply have the NFT owner transfer the NFT back to your account to receive the physical good. You'd just have to ensure the correct person is getting the goods (ensure the same person who transferred you the NFT is the one you send the goods to.)

text: ah yeah true the website part, nice. i think actually in our case the person would keep NFT & physical piece. no need to return basically. we'd have several NFTs..ok will think about it. Thank you!

yeah, there's lots to think about. The main reason for taking back thr NFT is to ensure that you can keep track of how many physical goods are meant to be given out in relation to the NFTs minted. The way I think of this is when the NFT is sent, it can be bruned and a new NFT created. The NFT could be almnost exactly the same, but the first one could have [not redeemed] in the metadata somewhere, and then the NFT received after would have [redeemed] in the metadata.

messages.text: This way the buyer still gets to hold an NFT to commemorate the purchace, but cant use that same NFT to try and redeem more physical goods.

Also if they tried to resell the NFT on the marketplace it would be clear to the rest of the potential buyers that the NFT would not be redeemable because it already had been redeemed. the NFT would only be valueable for its on chain attributes instead of the ability to be exchanged for a physical good.

aaah I see. ok. I didn't think about that detail, good one. I was thinking if we would add somewhere that the first sale includes the physical part, then it can be resold without any issue regarding that.

The only issue there is that then people can't resell the NFT which is where a lot of value can come from as a creator. For example, the NFT may be traded 100 times before it gets redeemed. With a 10% royalty fee üòÖ, that pays for the asset without ever having sent anything out.

Also, the value of the piece may go up over time. For example, a pair of socks on etherium (unisocks) are worth over 100k üòÖ (actually only 38k these days apparently). The tokens are traded constantly and only redeemed for socks when someone wants to make that transfer. A ton of economic activity is generated without anyone actually having to worry about the physical goods.

If you had 10 total goods and 9/10 sold for example, maybe the 10th one will stay as an NFT and never get redeemed, but it could still trade multiple times on the marketplace, which could still earn profit for the creator.
Only 23 more socks available and they are currently ~40k USD.

yes there is a way. It is possible to create an "implicit account" and transfer credits to it. And the access key is then just included in the URL. Here's an example where I've transferred 20 credits ( try it in private browsing mode to make sure it doesn't use your NEAR account ):

messages.text: How many copies (or editions?) are there?
I‚Äôve only made one for this song, but there are orher tracks there too. Also some with no owners yet.
Is it the track being sold or the track and the animation?
Only the track. The animation is a special ¬´exhibition¬ª, but the owner receives one listening credit for every visit in the music space trail exhibition.
How is the trail made? Is that for sale too? If you own the track can you always watch it with the trail or is that temporary?

There are two NFTs involved for the trail. One for the track, one for the instruments ( synth ). When you own the track, you only pay one credit for the synth. I‚Äôm planning to keep the trail permanent, and also add more tracks to it.
So if you own the track you can always see the visualization?
If you own the track and the synth yes
If you only own the track then you still have to pay one credit for the synth when visiting the trails
It‚Äôs this way because in the editor you create tracks based on an instrument NFT. When you publish a track and some buys it, it becomes another NFT, with ties to the instrument NFT
The animation is made using threejs btw
We are open to collaboration ideas with anyone.  Feel free to contact if interested.

messages.text: is $32 not enough for gas fees to receive 50 Near into my metamask wallet?

We're not really the support for the bridge unfortunately, but like I mentioned above, you want to keep an eye on the ETH gas, as it changes constantly and might raise or lower the amonnt you need to pay to confirm a transaction. You can probably set the gas to the amount you can afford in the "advanced" setting (gwei) and wait for it to reach that level. Hope that helps!

I personally wish the process was easier. Maybe look into opening a Binance account (depending where you're located) or find someone in your country in one of the groups you can exchange with directly?

messages.text:
Jah Zone - Life Taste 

Jah Zone representing Limbe City brings the sound of the streets to his music, furthermore he is the first crypto artist from Cameroon. Heavily involved in education of people around him about NFT, NEAR and crypto space, which contributes to improving the lives of his closest friends and family. Jah started his music career when he was 8 years old, performing and singing live on the streets. He has decided to follow his musical talent, as his music gives people enjoyment - this is what motivates him to action. Jah Zone is 

‚ÄúLife Taste‚Äù is the first studio album by Jah Zone. Music was made by producers, such as: Pepanic, Oboski, Paul Crans and JCBBeats. The atmosphere of ‚ÄúLife Taste‚Äù is oscillating between catchy ragga drums, dance melodies and overall is completed by the Hip-Hop vibe with original flow. Lyrics will take you to another world, seen by Jah Zone where you can experience his feelings and energy.

Full album will be available to unlock only for 7 NEAR after NFT purchase in DAOrecords‚Äô shop on Mintbase. Only 30 copies will be minted.


Tracklist:

Life Taste (prod. By Pepanic) 
Twerk (prod. By Pepanic) 
FILO (prod. By Pepanic) 
Point And Kill (prod. By Pepanic) 
Flames (prod. By Pepanic) 
No Water No Neppa (prod. By Oboski) 
E Don Stay (prod. By Pepanic) 
E Don Change (prod. By Pepanic) 
My Way (prod. By Pepanic)
We Need Peace (prod. By JCBBeats)
Hustle (prod. By Paul Crans)
Thank you! I will do some more!

[10/17, 2:13 AM] Lebon: For a music artist, the lack of financial resources is a main obstacle to fulfill their career hopes. Covibes is a platform that facilitates music artists to sell their artistic projects and receive financial contributions directly from their fans, as well as crowdfunding for a specific verified project on the platform, such as working with a great producer, recording in a high-end music studio, crowdfunding for the production of an album or a track. 

By taking 5 minutes to complete this survey, you will understand how we can financially support you on your career path. Our goal is to help artists like you "fund your dreams with peace of mind".

‚ÄúLife Taste‚Äù is the first studio album by Jah Zone. Music was made by producers, such as: Pepanic, Oboski, Paul Crans and JCBBeats. messages.text: So, the Discord vs Telegram questions was put to the community many months ago. At the time the overwhelming response was a preference for Telegram. Many new member have joined since then. It may be time to re-evaluate.

text: Nice, I've been looking for something like this for a while... Thanks for that

messages.text: Maybe we can run a poll in here and see what the majority prefers?
I down for whatever. I like Discord better, but I've learned to deal with Telegram now so...

Really, I think we have to be on both if we want to reach the most people outside the community. As much as I'd like to only look at one or the other, there are things about both that appeal to different people. There are people who hate Discord and will never get on there and vise versa.

Also, I hope eveyone is looking at the governance forum regularly. I find it the best way to stay up to date with everything going on in our guild and the broader Near ecosystem.

Hello NxM

Besides that I have a more conventional Art direction practice for diverse sectors, and would like to do more in Music:

I`m currently in Portugal, but my base is Rio de Janeiro, (I`m brazilian)
I have been nomading around, so geography is not an issue for me.
Please let me know if you have any projects my work could be a Match.
